title: Friday, 3rd June, 2016

PM

He runs ViiV Healthcare, the Glaxo led JV getting people in places like Africa better

PM

Viiv have announced this this moring..

PM

Agreement supports the first ‘Treat All’ programme for HIV in sub-Saharan Africa, where 70% of people with HIV live[1]

London, UK, Friday 3 June, 2016 – ViiV Healthcare, a global specialist HIV company majority owned by GSK, with Pfizer Inc. and Shionogi Limited as shareholders, today confirmed a public tender agreement with the Ministry of Health in Botswana to support the implementation of a new national ‘Treat All’ programme which aims to ensure people living with HIV in the country get tested and receive treatment. This is the first time dolutegravir will be made available as part of a national health programme in sub-Saharan Africa since the WHO recommended dolutegravir as alternative first line treatment in HIV patients in late 2015.[2]

This is the largest tender ever secured by ViiV Healthcare in the African sub-continent, a region particularly impacted by the HIV epidemic with nearly three quarters of the global HIV population living there.1 As part of the agreement, ViiV Healthcare has committed to providing dolutegravir 50mg. The medicine would be used as a first linecore-agent to treat newly diagnosed patients tested under the programme in Botswana.

11:09 am
PM

Elga Bartsch and team at Morgan Stanley

PM

Even though the ECB President was careful not to commit to any future policy action today, the dovishness of his remarks and the unchanged projections for 2017/18 underscore the ECB's easing bias.

PM

To our and the market's surprise, the Eurosystem staff only made very cosmetic changes to their projections for growth and inflation over the policy relevant horizon of 2017-18. This was surprising because the staff of the ECB and the national central banks (NCB) not only had to factor in a new set of macro assumptions regarding oil prices, interest rates and exchange rates, but also had to model the impact of the measures announced at the March meeting.

11:10 am
PM

Leaving growth and inflation forecasts unchanged despite a comprehensive package of March measures being implemented suggests that either the staff does not share the Governing Council's optimism on the effectiveness of these monetary policy measures or that the staff identified offsetting factors, e.g., greater spillover effects from the current low headline inflation into underlying price pressures and wage dynamics

PM

The dovish tilt of today's meeting underscores our call that the ECB will likely ease policy further in the second half of the year. Our current forecast pencils in another deposit rate cut in September, in line with the ECB's forward guidance. Currently, about two thirds of all ECB watchers are expecting further easing in H2 and about half of the ECB watching community has their eyes on September, according to Bloomberg. While our view of another rate cut is only shared by about 40% of the experts, more than 80% expect additional QE to be announced by the ECB.

PM

As before, the introductory statement highlights that the Governing Council intends to leave interest rates at this or a lower level for an extended period of time and until well after the end of its asset purchase programme (currently scheduled for March 2017). While the Council is confident that the decisions taken in early March will "underpin recovery and fosters the return of inflation to levels below, but close to, 2%.", it will "closely monitor the evolution of the outlook for price stability and, if warranted to achieve its objective, will act by using all the instruments available within its mandate."

11:10 am
PM

In this context, the introductory statement stresses the downside risks surrounding the growth outlook, while - as before - not explicitly commenting on the risks around the inflation outlook. The downside risks to growth are seen to come from developments in the global economy, the upcoming British referendum, and other geopolitical risks. In this context, the Council acknowledges though that "the balance of risks has improved on the back of the monetary policy measures taken and the [policy] stimulus still in the pipeline".

PM

Fielding a number of questions on future policy action and the ECB's easing bias during the Q&A, Draghi outlined that the ECB would act with out undue delay if either an unwanted tightening in financial conditions materially altered the medium-term outlook for price stability, or if the low headline inflation caused some persistent second round effects, notably in the wage-setting process. We know from the accounts of the April meeting that the latter point is subject to an intense debate on the Council. Today, however, the ECB was not ready to commit to another round of stimulus yet. At the same time, Draghi was quick to stress that the ECB was prepared for all contingencies that could occur around a potential vote of the UK to leave the European Union. Interestingly, our own FCI suggests that, based on the partial May data available thus far, we might have seen a noticeable tightening in euro area financial conditions. If this tightening is confirmed by the full data-set, the ECB might want to take note.

PM

BE

11:15 am
BE

(Anil Agarwal's at this year's CAV, of course.)

BE

Here's the upshot.

BE

Noble Group today announced a fully underwritten rights issue with net
proceeds of approximately USD500m. Of the total 6.54bn shares to be issued,
Mr. Elman has agreed to take on 625.5m while CIC has agreed to take on
630.6m. CIC will also get a second board seat in Noble. The rights issue is
subject to share holders approval. In addition, Noble also confirmed the sale of
NAES (target completion 2H16), sale of other non-core assets, and a working
capital reduction program – all of which is expected to generate at least
USD1.5bn in liquidity. The aggregate total of USD2bn in additional
capital/liquidity raise is expected to address the bank debts due in 2017. On
the operational side, Noble confirmed that cost discipline remains in focus with
planned headcount and SAO expense reduction in excess of 20% from current
levels over the course of 2016 (including impact from planned sale of NAES).
Mr. Elman wishes to step down as executive chairman within 12 months.

11:15 am
BE

Credit thoughts
Fundamentally this could be viewed as a game changer for Noble and
demonstrates its commitment to the stated strategy. We calculate NAES sale
to fetch an EV of around USD1bn. Per management, NAES is now debt-free
and at any point in time carries about USD300-500m of working capital that
management expects to also be released. On a pro-forma basis, USD500m of
fresh equity brings Noble’s net gearing to 45% from 52% as at March 2016.
This also happens to be Noble’s target gearing by year end. We have not been
able to speak with rating agencies but we feel this should halt Noble’s negative
rating momentum. In fact, we wouldn’t rule out the possibility of an upgrade if
Noble continues to deliver on the pledged liquidity initiatives.

BE

Hm.

BE

Upgrading the Perps to Buy
As we write, the Noble bonds are up ~10 points on average across the curve.
We continue to struggle finding good comps for this credit, using Vedanta as
the best available alternative. Fundamentally, we still prefer Vedanta. Noble
2018s (90 offer, 9.9% ytm) and 2020s (86.5 offer, 11.4%) are trading well
inside Vedanta 2018s (94 offer, 12.8% ytm) and 2021s (79 offer, 14.4% ytm),
and don’t look cheap from a RV perspective. We do agree that Noble likely has
more positive news coming (asset sales, etc.) than Vedanta. Interestingly, the
perps (65 offer) have performed broadly in line with the straights, up around 40
points from the lows, and offer more upside in our view. Management has also
demonstrated its commitment to keep paying the perp coupons even in the
worst of times and even as dividends are not being paid. Plus, the rights offer
means that privatization is likely off the table for now. We don’t have a strong
view that the perps will be called in 2019 (especially given lack of high step
up), but do find the running carry of almost 10% (with 6% coupon) attractive,
even if it’s not called. Hence, we upgrade them to Buy, while maintaining Hold
on the 2018s and 2020s.

11:21 am
BE

On June 2 we visited RR’s main Civil Aero (CA) facilities in Derby, UK. We came away with a much more positive impression than we did on our last visit (Sept 2013), when we wrote that “we were somewhat underwhelmed by the sense of urgency [on cost reduction] in the CA division.” Clearly a lot has happened since then (5 group-level profit warnings, new group CEO, new group CFO, new head of CA). On this trip we met Mike Mosley, head of CA’s global operations, who was clear that RR is no longer in denial about the need for change, and that the process is underway. We remain Neutral rated on the shares given significant near-term headwinds across the group and a full valuation (on 2016-18E earnings). However, given RR’s current low earnings, any cost savings beat would have a fairly large impact on EPS estimates.

BE

· “Real signs” of positive change: In mid-2011 then (new) CEO John Rishton announced his intentions to cut RR’s costs and improve its cash generation. So when we visited Derby in Sept 2013 we were very disappointed to see little evidence of cultural change and a total lack of posters and “visual management displays”. This may sound rather simplistic but any investor who has visited a factory engaged in six-sigma lean manufacturing kaizen etc. will be familiar with the “call to action” motivation posted and, more importantly, the prominent visual displays showing key metrics like scrap rates overdue work stock turns etc. The good news is that Derby today has plenty of these posters (some examples overleaf) and visual management displays (unsurprisingly we weren’t allowed to take photos of these). We came away with the impression that “Derby now gets it”, perhaps unsurprisingly after a slew of profit warnings.

BE

"visual management displays"! Coo!

11:22 am
BE

· Better ‘line of sight’ over the business: Mr Mosley said the CA business had robust data on the cost of products, but in the past a lot of this data was in different silos. Today this data is being shared and RR feels that for the first time it has ‘line of sight’ across the whole CA enterprise.

BE

There's lots more of this. Unsure how interested the ROTR are in process management at a factory in Derby.

BE

Let's find out, I guess.

11:23 am
BE

· Delayering of management: Recent management redundancies mean there are now typically 7-8 layers between the CEO and shop floor, compared to 9-11 layers.

BE

· More outsourcing, and more to low cost countries: For many years RR has produced c30% of its engine parts and outsourced 70%. It is now moving to 20%-80%. (We believe that RR could achieve this by the end of this decade although it hasn’t given a formal target.) In addition, it is finding new suppliers in low cost countries.

BE

· “Pulse lines” for engine assembly: Volumes in the CA industry are relatively low (c1,500 large aircraft pa) which means fully automated flow production lines are not really suited to CA. However, RR is now assembling engines on “pulse lines”, a hybrid solution where some work is done in a stationary cell and then moved on the next station. On our last visit, some RR engines were some being assembled on wooden pallets.

11:23 am
BE

That's worth 2.6% on Rolls this morning. Wooden pallets versus stationary cells.

BE

Remember when we did M&A? Now it's assembly lines.

BE

So instead, let's have some Barclays on the sector.

11:32 am
BE

Downstream profitability has defied market expectations over the past 18 months,
generating 47% of cashflow for the European IOCs. The consensus view is that this is
unsustainable windfall profitability. Our view is somewhat different. We expect
earnings and cashflow across the downstream to prove more resilient than many
anticipate. Yes, it is true that refining margins have fallen back from year-ago levels,
but those margins remain well above the levels that prevailed when the oil price was
averaging above $100/bl and the contributions of marketing, lubricants and
petrochemicals provide a core level of profitability that should not be ignored. More
important is the structural reform of the downstream businesses over the past five
years, which included a 12% reduction in headcount and 20% reduction in refining
capacity that should lead to meaningfully more resilient businesses even with lower
margins. The outlook for free cash flow should also be reassuring for investors.
Downstream capex in the coming five years is set to average 25% lower than the
previous five years and close to depreciation. This should be supportive of dividends
for BP, RDS and Total, and for Repsol and GALP, this is a source of FCF that we see as
undervalued. We rate both Repsol (PT EUR16) and GALP (PT EUR15) as Overweight.

BE

Downstream is about more than just refining: As the oil price recovers, we assume
that refining margins will trend down over the coming two years. Yet despite this we do
not expect a collapse in downstream profitability. Instead we forecast downstream
cashflows for the sector 30% above the 2011-14 average. This reflects the combination
of profitability offered from marketing, lubricants, trading and petrochemicals as well as
the impact of restructuring.
Businesses restructured, FCF generation the focus: Given the multitude of business
lines that make up the downstream business, it is important to examine the
restructuring and the changes in the underlying cost base that have taken place over
the past five years. A prolonged period of $100/bl oil distorted the cost base and the
resulting period of low margins in 2009-13 finally forced material restructuring.
Headcount across the sector is down 27% in the past 10 years, refining capacity has
fallen 20% and marketing volumes relative to refining have risen 10%. All of this has
given rise to what we see as better profitability and just as importantly more sustainable
FCF with the restructuring costs and associated capex coming to an end.
Total, Repsol and GALP the most significant beneficiaries: Within this report, we
examine the evolution of the downstream business for the relevant Integrated Oils in
Europe. The material improvements in terms of capacity and efficiency across the entire
group are on evident. Total has made the largest relative improvement in returns while
BP has reduced its overall refining footprint the most. For Repsol and GALP, the
significant investments over 2006-2011 now leaves both with a materially free cash
flow positive business that will support the upstream through a period of low prices.

BE

Not sure I entirely get the logic there. Investment levels are unsustainably low, basically little more than depreciation rates, so that underpins dividends.

11:34 am
BE

Either that or it suggests investment levels are unsustainably low and any oil price rebound will disappear into correcting that, irrelevant to yields.

BE

In FY06 & FY07 a c.6% price reduction drove short-term volume growth of
14% at M&S. However, over the last 10 years the market share held by value
retailers has grown by over 500bps and online penetration has increased by
c.15% points. This time around M&S is operating in a significantly more
competitive environment, and reducing prices by only 2%. Volume uplifts are
therefore likely to be materially lower than in the past. We reduce our FY17
PBT forecast by 14% and our FY18 & FY19 forecasts by greater than 20% implying flat
PBT growth in these later years. We apply a 30% discount to the FY18 sector
average PE to arrive at our new TP of 307p. With a further 14% downside
implied, we reduce our recommendation to UW.

11:45 am
BE

 Deflation rate in the clothing market is -6%, but we expect the average
selling price at M&S to fall by only 2%. Although M&S is lowering
headline prices, we expect this to be materially offset by reduced markdown
activity. Overall therefore we expect an average achieved selling price
reduction of only c.2% in Clothing, versus deflation in the Clothing market
of -6% in the last year. We note that in FY07 Clothing market deflation was
-4% versus price reductions at M&S of c.6%.

BE

 Gross margin story has run its course. The moving parts in the M&S
Clothing & Home gross margin where we have some visibility, and can
therefore attempt to estimate, would imply a FY17 gross margin decline of -
20bps. This implies a gap of at least 70bps that M&S must bridge to reach
guidance of +50-100bps (JPMe +50bps). We therefore believe that the risk
to this range lies to the downside.

BE

 Cautious on the Food outlook. We forecast a flat FY17 Food gross
margin. But with ongoing pressure in the market and some signs of LFL
weakness, we believe the risk to the Food gross margin lies to the downside.
 Reduce TP to 307p. The shares have fallen 34% since November 2015.
However, based on FY18E EPS, where we now assume only flat PBT
following a decline of 10% in FY17E, the stock is trading at a discount to
the sector of 18%, versus a 4-year historic average of 22%. As recently as
January M&S was trading at a discount of 30%. We apply a 30% discount/
FY18 PE multiple of 10.0x to arrive at our new, Mar-17 TP of 307p.

11:45 am

11:55 am
BE

Hardly any brokers cover Alliance -- because why bother, you take the NAV and subtract however big a discount you think is appropriate -- but Winterfloods wrote on it earlier in the week.

BE

This is Simon Elliott, and I'll post in full as it's a few days old.

BE

If this were a Jane Austen novel, Alliance Trust would be a maturing Dundonian maid about to be overwhelmed by the attention of a range of handsome suitors. Alliance Trust (ATST) has confirmed an informal approach from RIT Capital Partners (RCP) regarding a possible merger. In accordance with the City Code on Takeovers and Mergers, RCP now has until 27 June to make a firm offer, with ATST suspending share buybacks during this period. The Chairman of ATST also noted the Board’s ongoing strategic review, the outcome of which “may not be determined for some months.”

Informal approaches are not uncommon in the investment trust sector and usually remain unreported as very few progress. A cynic would argue that 'turkeys tend not to vote for Christmas' referring to the difficulty that boards of directors have in contemplating their own demise. However, we believe that in this instance the approach should be taken seriously as it has clear merits for both sets of shareholders. Interestingly, according to media reports RCP has a stake of around 3% in ATST.

RCP has an excellent long term risk-adjusted performance record in following its aim to “deliver long-term capital growth, while preserving shareholders’ capital”. The fund invests across asset classes, including both public and private equity and has many of the attributes of a family office. Furthermore it has consistently traded at a premium to its peer group, and often at a premium to its NAV, reflecting both its performance and strong retail following. While Lord Rothschild has been intimately involved in RIT Capital Partners since its launch, it is worth noting that there is an experienced and highly regarded team, led by Ron Tabbouche, which is responsible for investment.

Suffice to say that despite a significant number of changes to both investment managers and approaches, the performance of Alliance Trust remains uninspiring, while its discount of 10% is supported by an active buyback policy. Since October last year 37.3m shares have been bought in at a cost of £186m and equivalent to 6.8% of the share register. This has led some to question the sustainability of the single-digit discount target made last year.

11:56 am
BE

By merging with RCP, it is reasonable to assume that shareholders in ATST would benefit from a substantial narrowing of its discount and exposure to a vehicle that has been more successful in achieving its objectives. In addition, as both are self-managed investment trusts, there should be a fall in the cost base and therefore ongoing charge ratio. Shareholders in RCP would similarly see the benefits of spreading costs over a wider pool of assets. In addition it is possible that there could be some slight uplift to NAV, depending on whether the deal would be done on a NAV for NAV basis or a slight premium in favour of RCP shareholders. Shareholders in RCP would see its exposure to direct unquoted holdings (currently 10% of NAV) diluted by the merger, but we believe that this would be outweighed by long term benefits.

In any merger we would assume that there would be a potential cash exit at NAV less costs for ATST shareholders. Certainly this would be well received by Elliott Associates, an activist investor and the fund's largest shareholder (excluding Alliance Trust Savings) with 16% of the share capital. While this is likely to result in a substantial outflow of capital, given the starting point of £2.9bn of net assets, we would still expect to see a considerable amount rolling over into RCP.

The Board of Alliance Trust is now better placed to opine on this type of proposal following the reorganisation last year. ATST's board is now fully independent of either of its main operating subsidiaries. In theory any merger would be complicated by the presence of these businesses but RCP has shown that it is prepared to invest in fund management companies. The most recent example is GVQ Investment Management, manager of Strategic Equity Capital. Similarly we suspect RCP would be an excellent parent of Alliance Trust Savings given their experience in developing businesses such as St James' Place.

In our opinion the opportunity to merge with RIT Capital Partners is one the Board of Alliance Trust should take seriously. Although no doubt an array of alternative options will be presented, this one has the advantage of potentially being able to accommodate the subsidiary businesses as well as offering a proven investment solution. We believe a merger between Alliance Trust and RIT Capital Partners has much to commend it.

BE
